DataElement.preferredName: Cytogenetic Analysis And/Or Molecular Analysis Laboratory Procedure BCR-ABL Oncoprotein And Philadelphia Chromosome Positive Finding Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the type of cytogenetic and or molecular abnormality that showed a positive finding.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Cytogenetic Analysis And/Or Molecular Analysis Laboratory Procedure BCR-ABL Oncoprotein And/Or Philadelphia Chromosome Positive Finding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities._Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level._Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._An onco-protein generated from the fusion of Bcr and Abl genes by translocation process between chromosome 9 and 22 (Philadelphia chromosome), in CML (P210) and some ALL (P190). Aberrant expression of BCR-ABL in bone marrow cells results in a variety of leukemias._Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._A translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. It is the hallmark for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML)._An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Cytogenetic Analysis And/Or Molecular Analysis Laboratory Procedure
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.:Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options:Techniques for studying or analyzing the genetic composition and mechanisms of living organisms at the molecular level. May refer to the understanding and manipulation of genes (DNA).:Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Concepts.definition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredName: BCR-ABL Oncoprotein And/Or Philadelphia Chromosome Positive Finding
Property.preferredDefinition: An onco-protein generated from the fusion of Bcr and Abl genes by translocation process between chromosome 9 and 22 (Philadelphia chromosome), in CML (P210) and some ALL (P190).:Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options:An abnormality of chromosome 22 in which part of chromosome 9 is transferred to it.  Bone marrow cells that contain the Philadelphia chromosome are often found in chronic myelogenous leukemia.:An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Concepts.definition: A fusion protein encoded by the BCR/ABL1 fusion gene. This protein is comprised of the N-terminus of the breakpoint cluster region protein fused to almost the entire tyrosine-protein kinase ABL1 protein.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
A translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. It is the hallmark for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).
A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An onco-protein generated from the fusion of Bcr and Abl genes by translocation process between chromosome 9 and 22 (Philadelphia chromosome), in CML (P210) and some ALL (P190).: Covalent DNA changes in cells during normal differentiation resulting in new sequences, expression, or gene products; this is a mechanism of binding site diversification for antibodies, certain receptors, and possibly other proteins. The ordered rearrangement of gene regions by DNA recombination such as that which occurs normally during development. This includes the ordered rearrangement of variable gene regions; especially, the rearrangement of antibody genes during the differentiation of B-lymphocytes and the rearrangement of T-cell antigen receptor genes.

Concepts.definition: A fusion protein encoded by the BCR/ABL1 fusion gene. This protein is comprised of the N-terminus of the breakpoint cluster region protein fused to almost the entire tyrosine-protein kinase ABL1 protein.

Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the creation of a novel protein-coding capacity. Within certain genes, gene rearrangement is a normal part of development, facilitating the affinity maturation of B and T lymphocytes as well as class switching of immunoglobulins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An abnormality of chromosome 22 in which part of chromosome 9 is transferred to it.  Bone marrow cells that contain the Philadelphia chromosome are often found in chronic myelogenous leukemia.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.

Concepts.definition: A translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. It is the hallmark for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.
